moves.1. c4 e5 2. Nc3 Nc6: A standard set-up against the English opening but could transpose into something else at this point.
moves.3. g3 Nf6 4. Bg2 Bc5 5. e3 d6 6. Nge2 O-: A quiet way for white to play.
moves.8. d4 exd4 9. exd4 Bf5 10. a3 Na5 11. b3: This is the start of problems for white. I have two powerful bishops and the e file.
moves.14. Rc1 c6 15. d5 Rac8: A good way to contain the light- squared bishop which is no longer a powerful piece.
moves.16. h3 Qe5 17. Kh2: kh2? Moving from one unsafe diagonal to another.
moves.17... a6 18. f4 Qf6: Black is strong here and white is over- commit ed and weakening his king position.
moves.19. g4: g4? Is asking for a standard sacrifice which will lead to a bad game for white.
moves.19... Bxg4 20. hxg4 Qh4+ 21. Bh3 Re3: Re3! Making use of the undefended e file and white resigned here--the continuation:
moves.22. Ng1 Qg3+ 23. Kh1 Rxc3 24. Rxc3 Qxc3: A classic battle encounter in any war; Black is behind enemy lines, attacking, while his king position is secure.
